femtograd 0.9000

    • femtograd: Introduction

    femtograd: Introduction

    femtograd-intro.Rmd

    Here’s a quick demonstration of how to use the femtograd R package.

    Load it like this:

    library(femtograd)

    Exponential distribution

    Let’s create a simple loglikelihood function for the exponential distribution paramterized by \(\lambda\) (failure rate).

    We have \[ f_{T_i}(t_i | \lambda) = \lambda \exp(-\lambda t_i). \] So, the loglikelihood function is just \[ \ell(\lambda) = n \log \lambda - \lambda \sum_{i=1}^n t_i. \]

    Let’s generate \(n=30\) observations.

    n <- 30
true_rate <- 1
data <- rexp(n,true_rate)
head(data)
#> [1] 2.75829119 2.99712776 1.62604181 1.46694864 0.80658921 0.04568321

(mle.rate <- abs(1/mean(data)))
#> [1] 0.8224686

    We see that the MLE \(\hat\theta\) is 0.8224686. Let’s solve for the MLE iteratively as a demonstration of how to use femtograd. First, we construct the log-likelihood function.

    loglike_exp <- function(rate, data)
{
  return(log(rate)*length(data) - rate * sum(data))
}

    Initially, we guess that \(\hat\lambda\) is \(5\), which is a terrible estimate.

    rate <- val(-100)

    Next, we find the MLE using a simple iteration (100 loops).

    # to prevent taking too large of a step
# gradients are a local feature, so we don't want to make too big of jumps
grad_clip <- function(grad, max_norm = 1)
{
  norm <- sqrt(sum(grad * grad))
  if (norm > max_norm)
    grad <- (max_norm / norm) * grad
  grad
}

loglik <- loglike_exp(rate, data)
#> Warning in log(x$data): NaNs produced
for (i in 1:20)
{
  zero_grad(loglik)
  backward(loglik)

  rate$data <- rate$data + 0.01 * grad_clip(rate$grad)
  cat("loglike =", loglik$data, ", rate =", rate$data, ", score =", rate$grad, "\n")
}
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.01 , score = -36.77555 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.02 , score = -36.77552 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.03 , score = -36.77549 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.04 , score = -36.77546 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.05 , score = -36.77543 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.06 , score = -36.7754 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.07 , score = -36.77537 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.08 , score = -36.77534 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.09 , score = -36.77531 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.1 , score = -36.77528 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.11 , score = -36.77525 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.12 , score = -36.77522 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.13 , score = -36.7752 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.14 , score = -36.77517 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.15 , score = -36.77514 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.16 , score = -36.77511 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.17 , score = -36.77508 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.18 , score = -36.77505 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.19 , score = -36.77502 
#> loglike = NaN , rate = -100.2 , score = -36.77499

    Did it converge to the MLE?

    (converged <- (abs(mle.rate - rate$data) < 1e-3))
#> [1] FALSE

    It’s worth pointing out that we did not update loglik in the loop, since we only needed the gradient (score) to do that particular gradient ascent. If, however, we had used the log-likelihood value at rate, for instance using a line search method to avoid having to specify a step size, then we would need to update loglik each time through the loop.

    Weibull distribution

    Now let’s do it for a slightly more complicated distribution, Weibull.

    loglike_weibull <- function(shape, scale, data)
{
  n <- length(data)
  s <- sum_values(lapply(data, function(x) (val(x) / scale)^shape))
  a <- sum_values(lapply(data, function(x) log(val(x) / scale)))
  
  val(n) * log(shape/scale) + (shape - val(1)) * a - s
}

n <- 30
true_shape <- 10
true_scale <- 29
data <- rweibull(n, true_shape, true_scale)

shape <- val(5)
scale <- val(5)
shape.v <- 0
scale.v <- 0
beta <- .9
lr <- 0.01
for (i in 1:20)
{
  loglik <- loglike_weibull(shape, scale, data)
  zero_grad(loglik)
  backward(loglik)
  
  # we updated loglik so we can show the updated log-likelihood
  cat("loglike =", loglik$data, ", dl/dk =", shape$grad, ", dl/ds =", scale$grad, "\n")

  # update velocity with momentum
  shape.v <- beta * shape.v + grad_clip(shape$grad, max_norm=10)
  scale.v <- beta * scale.v + grad_clip(scale$grad, max_norm=10)

  # update parameters
  shape$data <- shape$data + lr * shape.v
  scale$data <- scale$data + lr * scale.v
}
#> loglike = -207042.9 , dl/dk = -373394.5 , dl/ds = 207219.9 
#> loglike = -156880.9 , dl/dk = -279717.5 , dl/ds = 150890.4 
#> loglike = -94095.82 , dl/dk = -164225 , dl/ds = 83914.63 
#> loglike = -46957.73 , dl/dk = -79554.53 , dl/ds = 37587.4 
#> loglike = -20492.35 , dl/dk = -33475.94 , dl/ds = 14283.58 
#> loglike = -8183.445 , dl/dk = -12821.99 , dl/ds = 4819.717 
#> loglike = -3111.397 , dl/dk = -4646.204 , dl/ds = 1495.63 
#> loglike = -1170.986 , dl/dk = -1634.912 , dl/ds = 435.2325 
#> loglike = -463.5657 , dl/dk = -559.9916 , dl/ds = 118.0325 
#> loglike = -220.8143 , dl/dk = -174.0202 , dl/ds = 28.08275 
#> loglike = -154.9905 , dl/dk = -22.11967 , dl/ds = 4.669649 
#> loglike = -182.7649 , dl/dk = 164.1493 , dl/ds = 0.1100909
#> Warning in log(x$data): NaNs produced
#> loglike = NaN , dl/dk = -78.96381 , dl/ds = 0.2858809
#> Warning in log(x$data): NaNs produced
#> loglike = NaN , dl/dk = -16.44773 , dl/ds = 1.43917
#> Warning in log(x$data): NaNs produced
#> loglike = NaN , dl/dk = 0.6292958 , dl/ds = 2.972896
#> Warning in log(x$data): NaNs produced
#> loglike = NaN , dl/dk = 7.0984 , dl/ds = 4.313319
#> Warning in log(x$data): NaNs produced
#> loglike = NaN , dl/dk = 9.549709 , dl/ds = 5.224598
#> Warning in log(x$data): NaNs produced
#> loglike = NaN , dl/dk = 10.16498 , dl/ds = 5.697357
#> Warning in log(x$data): NaNs produced
#> loglike = NaN , dl/dk = 9.791393 , dl/ds = 5.797314
#> Warning in log(x$data): NaNs produced
#> loglike = NaN , dl/dk = 8.780427 , dl/ds = 5.599797
print(c(shape=shape$data, scale=scale$data, loglike=loglik$data))
#>     shape     scale   loglike 
#> -2.892634 14.174488       NaN
